facts.text: On December 11, 1947, the appellant granted to the Shivrajpur Syndicate Ltd. rights for mining manganese ore from lands in villages Shivrajpur and Bhat.
Lease term: twelve years deemed to commence from December 1, 1945. Lessee to pay rent Rs. 2,629-8-8 and royalty at 8% of sale value of manganese ore.
Clause 1 of Part VII: Lessee to pay rent, royalty, and discharge all taxes, rates, assessments, impositions of public nature except land revenue.
Appellant received Rs. 16,309 in year ending July 31, 1951, and Rs. 39,515 in year ending July 31, 1952, from syndicate as 3/16th of rent and royalty, described as local fund cess.
Income-tax Officer taxed these sums for assessment years 1952-53 and 1953-54.

In appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, appellant contended sums not taxable as local fund cess collected on behalf of Government of Bombay or Local Board, or casual/non-recurring. AAC upheld and excluded sums.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held sums received under clause 1 Part VII, not as local fund cess on behalf of government, and not casual/non-recurring.
Tribunal referred under s.66(2) Income-tax Act: (1) Whether sums income? (2) If yes, exempt u/s 4(3)(vii) as casual/non-recurring?

Supplementary statement: Lands ceased to be alienated villages between Aug 1-15, 1950 due to Bombay Taluqdari Abolition Act 1949. Total assessment Rs.1,222.92, local fund cess Rs.270.45 nP., Jama payable to appellant Rs.504.45 nP. Cess as % of land revenue, not Jama.
High Court answered first question affirmatively (except amount of cess legally liable u/Bombay Local Boards Act), second negatively.
Local fund cess payable on two villages: Rs.270.45 (3/16ths of Rs.1,222.92 land revenue). Amounts paid by syndicate exceeded this.
Syndicate believed liable to pay cess at 3 annas per rupee on rent/royalty.

legal_issues.text: Whether the sum of Rs. 16,309/Rs. 39,515 received by the assessee from the syndicate is income for the purpose of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922?
If yes, whether exempt under section 4(3)(vii) as casual and non-recurring?

petitioner_arguments.text: Sums not taxable as they represented local fund cess collected on behalf of Government of Bombay or Local Board Panch Mahals.
In any event, receipts of casual and non-recurring nature exempt u/s 4(3)(vii).
Local fund cess on landholder under mining lease is fraction of aggregate rent/royalties per Government of Bombay instructions.

respondent_arguments.text: Sums received under clause 1 Part VII of lease, not as local fund cess on behalf of government.
Syndicate not inferior holder; liability on appellant as landholder.

court_reasoning.text: Amounts paid have quality closely similar to rents and royalty, directly related, hence taxable as income.
court_reasoning.key_observation: An amount paid under covenant directly related to payment of rent and royalty is taxable as income.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant did not collect as agent for government; syndicate discharged contractual obligation, excess over actual cess taxable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Difference between received and reimbursable amounts is income.

court_reasoning.text: ITO has jurisdiction to determine quantum of cess for tax purposes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: ITO is tribunal of exclusive jurisdiction for assessment.

court_reasoning.text: Manual instructions do not modify statutory rate of cess under Bombay Local Boards Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cess levied on land revenue at prescribed rate, not on Jama or royalties.

court_reasoning.text: Receipt not casual/non-recurring; not accidental or from unforeseen sources.

holdings.text: Sums received are income under Income-tax Act, 1922, except actual local fund cess legally payable.
Not exempt under s.4(3)(vii) as casual/non-recurring.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gopal Saran Narain Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Observation that anything properly described as income is taxable unless exempted.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of income; exemption for casual/non-recurring; reference to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Taluqdari Tenure Abolition Act, 1949 (62 of 1949)
statutes_cited.relevance: Extinguished Taluqdari tenure; lands liable for land revenue or Jama.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Definitions of superior holder, tenant; liability for land revenue on landholder.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Local Boards Act, 1923 (6 of 1923)
statutes_cited.relevance: Levy of local fund cess at 3 annas per rupee on land revenue; manner of levy.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed; sums received (excess over actual local fund cess) are taxable income, not casual/non-recurring.

key_quotes.text: "Anything which can properly be described as income, is taxable under the Act unless expressly exempted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Indicates broad scope of taxable income per Judicial Committee.

key_quotes.text: An amount which is paid under a covenant directly related to the payment of rent and royalty would... also be taxable as income.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on nature of receipts.

key_quotes.text: The Income-tax Officer is... a Tribunal of exclusive jurisdiction for the purpose of assessment of income-tax.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms ITO's power to determine taxability.
